The current in the first coil increases at a uniform rate of 800 A/s. 1. What is the magnitude of the induced emf in the second coil? Is it constant? 𝜀2 = −𝑀 𝑑𝑖1 𝑑𝑡 = −3 × 10−4 × 800 = −𝟎. 𝟐𝟒𝑽 (Yes, constant) 2. suppose that the current is instead in the 2nd coil, what is the magnitude of the induced emf in the 1st coil? 17 𝜀1 = −𝑀 𝑑𝑖2 𝑑𝑡 = −3 × 10 −4 × 800 = −𝟎. 𝟐𝟒𝑽 Application - Transformer 18 AC current in in primary coil induces a magnetic flux in the iron core. Assuming no flux leakage, the emf per turn is the same for primary and secondary coils. Hence 𝑉𝑝(𝑡) 𝑁𝑝 = 𝑉𝑠(𝑡) 𝑁𝑠 or 𝑉𝑠, 𝑟𝑚𝑠 = 𝑁𝑠 𝑁𝑝 𝑉𝑝, 𝑟𝑚𝑠 Transformers • Used to increase (step up) or decrease (step down) AC voltages. 19 Application 2 – Airport Metal Detectors • Pulsed current → pulsed magnetic field → Induces emf in metal • Ferromagnetic metals “draw in” more B → larger mutual inductance → larger emf • Emf → current (how much, how long it lasts, depends on the resistivity of the material) • Decaying current produces decaying magnetic field → induces current in receiver coils • Magnitude & duration of signal depends on the composition and geometry of the metal object 20 Application 3 • Pacemakers – It’s not easy to change the battery! – Instead, use an external AC supply. • Alternating current: → Alternating B-field → alternating flux m inside “wearer” → induces AC current to charge up pacemaker 21 Summary • Current in RL circuit when switched on 𝐼 𝑡 = 𝐼0 1 − 𝑒−𝑡 𝜏 • Mutual inductance from two coils: 𝑀 = 𝑁22 𝑖1 = 𝑁11 𝑖2 𝜀2 = −𝑀 𝑑𝑖1 𝑑𝑡 & 𝜀1 = −𝑀 𝑑𝑖2 𝑑𝑡 • AC Transformer 𝑉𝑝(𝑡) 𝑁𝑝 = 𝑉𝑠(𝑡) 𝑁𝑠 22
